Git workflow tools for PR management and worktrees.
    Supports PR checkout with gh/git fallback, browser PR viewing, and worktree operations.

Create a pull request using GitHub CLI.
    Supports automatic browser preview with customizable browser selection.

git:worktree.description:
Manage git worktrees: list existing worktrees, add new ones, remove, or prune stale entries.
    Git worktrees allow multiple working directories from a single repository.

examples.description: List all worktrees in friendly format
Add new worktree with auto-generated path
Switch to main worktree (outputs path for cd)
Switch to specific worktree by branch name

add.description: Add new worktree (auto-generates path if not specified)
add.name: add

switch.description: Get worktree path (outputs path only, use with: cd $(xling git:worktree -s -b <branch>))
switch.name: switch

path.description: Worktree path (e.g., '../repo-feature' or absolute path). Auto-generated if not specified with --add.
path.name: path

branch.description: Branch or worktree name. Defaults to main for --add and --switch. For --remove, intelligently matches branch or directory name.
branch.name: branch

git:wta.description:
Create a new git worktree with automatic path generation.
    Defaults to main branch if not specified.
    Use --select to choose a branch from an interactive list.

examples.description: Create a new feature branch from main in a new worktree
Create a detached worktree on main even if main is in use

path.description: Custom worktree path (auto-generated if not specified)
path.name: path

base.name: base

create.description: Create the branch if it does not exist (uses -b). Use --no-create to require existing branch.
create.name: create

select.description: Use an interactive selector to choose the branch
select.name: select

git:wtl.description:
List all git worktrees in a friendly format.
    Shows the path and branch for each worktree.

examples.description: List worktrees and filter for feature branches
List worktrees from another repo directory

git:wtp.description:
Remove stale worktree administrative files.
    This cleans up worktrees that have been manually deleted from the filesystem.

examples.description: Clean up after manually deleting a worktree folder
Prune then list worktrees to verify

git:wtr.description:
Remove a git worktree by branch name, directory name, or path.
    Intelligently matches branch or directory names.
    Use --select to pick which worktree to remove from an interactive list.

examples.description: Pick a worktree to remove interactively

select.description: Use an interactive selector to choose the worktree to remove
select.name: select

git:wts.description:
Find a matching worktree, then start a subshell rooted there.
    Defaults to the main branch if no branch/directory is provided.
    Use --path-only for scripting (outputs the path for cd $(...)).
    Use --select to pick a worktree from an interactive list.

examples.description: Switch to main worktree without subshell (path only)
Switch to specific worktree by branch name
Use interactive selector to pick a worktree

branch.description: Branch or worktree directory name (defaults to main)
branch.name: branch

path-only.description: Only print the worktree path (useful for cd $(...))
path-only.name: path-only

select.description: Use an interactive selector to choose the worktree
select.name: select

git:wts.summary: Switch to a git worktree (opens subshell by default)

proxy.description:
Boot a local proxy server that forwards requests to configured upstream AI providers.

Features:
- OpenAI-compatible API endpoints (/v1/chat/completions, /v1/messages, etc.)
- Multiple upstream providers with automatic failover
- Load balancing strategies: round-robin, random, weighted, failover
- API key rotation with automatic cooldown on errors
- Optional access key protection

Configuration is read from ~/.claude/xling.json under the 'proxy' section.

examples.description: Start proxy server on default port (4320)
Start on custom port with access key protection
Bind to all interfaces for external access

access-key.description: Access key for proxy authentication (overrides config file)
access-key.name: access-key

proxy.summary: Start an OpenAI-compatible proxy server with load balancing and key rotation

settings:auth.description:
Save, list, and delete auth profiles for Codex.
    Use settings:switch to switch between auth profiles and providers.

    Auth profiles allow you to save multiple Codex login credentials
    and switch between them without having to logout and login again.

examples.description: Save current auth as a named profile
Restore a saved auth profile back to auth.json

tool.description: AI CLI tool (currently only codex is supported)
tool.name: tool

save.description: Save current auth as a named profile
save.name: save

restore.description: Restore a saved auth profile back to auth.json
restore.name: restore

Print the entire configuration file for the selected tool/scope.
    Use --json for structured output or --no-json for plain text.

settings:set.description:
Create or open settings files for AI CLI tools in your preferred editor,
    or interactively add Codex model providers.

    For Claude: provide --name to edit settings.<name>.json (default: settings.json).
    For Codex: answer prompts to create a [model_providers.<name>] entry.
    For Xling: edits ~/.claude/xling.json configuration.

Open Claude project settings in Cursor without JSON output

settings:set.summary: Open settings files or add Codex providers

settings:switch.description:
Switch to a different profile configuration for Codex
    or activate a specific settings.<variant>.json for Claude.

    For Codex, you can switch between:
    - Auth profiles (saved login credentials)
    - Model providers (API endpoints)
    - Named profiles (from config.toml)

Copy Claude Code config.toml into Codex (default) or reverse the direction

    backup+overwrite, or cancel (similar to settings:switch).
    Use --force to skip prompts.

x.description:
Quick launcher for Claude Code, Codex, or Gemini CLI with yolo mode enabled by default.

    Just run "xling x" to start Claude Code instantly!

    Claude Code is launched by default. Use --tool flag to launch other tools.

    Yolo mode is ENABLED by default, which skips permission prompts:
    - Claude Code: --dangerously-skip-permissions
    - Codex: --dangerously-bypass-approvals-and-sandbox
    - Gemini CLI: -y

    Resume options:
    - Use -c/--continue to continue the last conversation/session
    - Use -r/--resume to show a list of conversations/sessions to resume

    Pass additional arguments after -- to forward them to the tool.

    Examples:
      $ xling x                          # Start Claude Code (fastest way!)
      $ xling x -c                       # Continue last Claude conversation
      $ xling x -r                       # Resume a Claude conversation (list)
      $ xling x -s hxi                   # Start Claude with hxi settings variant
      $ xling x -t codex -c              # Continue last Codex session
      $ xling x -t codex -s oss          # Start Codex with oss profile
      $ xling x --tool codex             # Start Codex
      $ xling x -t gemini                # Start Gemini CLI
      $ xling x -t gemini -c             # Resume latest Gemini session
      $ xling x --no-yolo                # Start Claude without yolo
      $ xling x -- chat "Hello"          # Start Claude with arguments
      $ xling x -t codex -C /path        # Start Codex in specific directory

examples.description: Start Claude with hxi settings variant

examples.command: <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -- chat "Hello, how are you?"

cwd.description: Working directory for the launched process
cwd.name: cwd

settings.description: Settings configuration (Claude: variant name or file path; Codex: profile name; Gemini: model name)
settings.name: settings

x.summary: eXecute AI CLI tools (defaults to Claude Code with yolo)
